_localizedContents._text:
You dream of a funeral, a dear friend has died. You see all the family and friends gathered around the hole in the ground, but you can't make out who they are. While every one is crying, a shadowy figure crawls out of the ground, crawling towards you.
You wake up in a pool of your own sweat. The light from outside your room gives it a cool yellow tint, making the shapes blurry. Your throat is parched. You reach out on the side of your bed and open the minifridge that you use as bed stand. You take out your water bottle and sip from it. The cold drink wakes you up.
You reach under your pillow to pull out your phone, it's 4.45am.

You don't remember much from the day before, but you know nothing interesting happened.
Every day is the same. You wake up, lay in bed on your phone, watch puppy videos all day or some new anime series that came out, eat when you're hungry, and then.....then it hits you. That gut wrenching feeling that crawls from the back of your neck to your stomach. That clawing pain from behind your eyeballs. All you can do is curl up on your mattress and pray for it to go away, like the most devote Christian running away from their sins: except that your sins have a shape, and voice.

You can feel them touch your back, caress your neck, whisper in your ear. They tell you how worthless you are. How much of a disappointment you've been to the people who were around you. How you'll never be forgiven, no matter how much you pray for it.
Every time the creature gives you two choices. Run away from your sins, or redeem yourself.

It's the minimum you can do to make up for the pain you've caused to others. One slice for her mother, who had to go through it all alone. One slice for her father, hoping that he will get his daughter back. One slice for your friends, who were powerless against it all. And one for ■■■■■■, who had to carry it to the tomb.
You watch as the droplets of blood seep out of the cuts, growing bigger and bigger, and eventually sliding off your arm, hitting the ground...plip...plip...plip.
Now you have to clean up this mess.
You head to the bathroom. You feel the wall in search for the light switch, and you flick it on.
You're greeted by your reflection in the mirror, someone you don't know.
You open the cabinet in search for bandages and disinfectant. Ok that you hate yourself but you still don't want an infection, the hospital is expensive.
You patch yourself up. You've done this so many times that you're as good as a nurse now.
You head back to the bed, your mind numb from the pain on your arm. You close your eyes, and drift off to a dreamless sleep.

The only thing that helps alleviate the pain is...not being there to feel it at all.
You reach in the crack between your mattress and the wall for your bottle of sleeping pills. You've been using them for a while, so every time you take them you have to increase the dosage for them to work.
You lay your head on your pillow, and close your eyes. Everything in your room begins to swirl in endless colors. Then everything fades to black. A restless sleep, haunted by vivid nightmares you can't remember; but it's still better than the pain of being aware that you're still alive, and she's not.

A thunder in the distance wakes you up. The rain pitter patters on your window, the sound soothes your nerves. Your throat is parched. You reach out on the side of your bed and open the minifridge that you use as bed stand. You take out your water bottle and sip from it. The cold drink wakes you up.
You reach under your pillow to pull out your phone, it's 2.26am.
You don't remember much from the day before, but you know nothing interesting happened.
You wonder what you're going to do today...
Try to draw in your sketch book

You decide to clean your room. You're tired of your own mess, and miraculously you feel energetic enough to do it. But there's so much stuff scattered around that you don't know where to start from...
You reach down your desk to turn on your dusty desktop, the screen flickers, while the vents start humming.

You start flipping through your sketchbook in search for inspiration...
You haven't drawn in months, so you don't think that today that is going to change.
You sketch out some lines of a face, add some eyes and a nose...you never knew how to draw people smiling. Every time you tried it would come out as an uncomfortable and off-putting smile.
You feel the guilt of having lost your drawing skills crawl up your throat...it's time to do something else before it gets worse.

Your home page is filled with manga pages and pictures of pretty people, with the occasional meme as well. All this fills your mind with an empty pleasant feeling of dread, knowing that if you chose a different path you could be one of those pretty people, or maybe working on your own comic, who knows... fantasizing on your future is better than acting for it.
On here you lose yourself for hours. Either watching funny gameplays, anime, or FUNNY CAT COMPILATION!!!...any of these are good to make you feel something.

For you this is a place to vent. Here you can turn your bloody aftermath pictures into something that other people like you will like. You know it's not healthy, but it helps to feel less alone...except that you wouldn't have discovered self harm if it weren't for this site. I guess it counts as a double edged sword.
You choose to do something else, what will you do?
Try to draw in your sketchbook

You open the closet just to find a mess of clothes scattered around. Some are hanged, left untouched. Others are piled up on the bottom of the closet. You can also see some boxes on the upper compartment. Where should you begin from?

You decided that taking out the clothes from the bottom would be the best way to approach it.
You shove your hand in the pile and start taking out everything one by one. You fold them neatly in piles and put them on the side. It's mostly black shirts and black hoodies, it's the only colour you feel comfortable in, since it hides body shapes pretty well.
Then you pull out a a black hoodie with red hems and white eyes painted on the sleeves and the bottom. You remember it being your favorite hoodie throughout all of high school, in fact you wore it so often that people thought you never washed it....can't say it's not true.
You fold it and put it together with the other hoodies.
After some time the only things left at the bottom of the closet are some mismatched socks, a belt and some black and red rags, of which you can't really figure out the use of.
You hold them out in front of yourself. They're about as long as your forearms, cylindrical in shape and with a hole on the side of them.
You remember. She made them for you.
It's fingerless gloves that cover your forearms, tight enough to simulate the pressure of bandages. She as worried about you. She wanted you to stop.
"They're pretty useless now, don't you think?" the creature whispers in your ear, "You don't have any reason to stop suffering, you deserve it."
You clutch the gloves tighter, your knuckles turning white.
it's time to do something else.

You don't remember what's in those boxes, and you're curious to find out.
You stretch your arms and grab the one on the left. You wipe the dust off of it, revealing a date on it, "2015-2018", it must be stuff from your middle school years. You open it.
There's some old textbooks and notebooks. A couple of sketchbooks and a folder. You open the folder. Inside there are some scattered pages from a notebook, they're full of a handwriting you don't recognize, all written in green. It's a story of a girl that gets lost in the woods, and a crow guides her home. You vaguely remember her hair getting caught on the pen while she was writing it.
The last thing left in the folder is a photograph. It's a bunch of kids smiling with their teachers, an end of the year picture. You can't find yourself in it, you were probably sick and couldn't come to school on that day, after all you always hated photographs. You see some familiar faces in it. You even see her. A heavy fringe on her face, eyes barely visible, and a soft smile.
"She was so pure, you ruined her". Your head is pounding, and your vision is fuzzy. You can feel it grabbing your neck, such a familiar pressure, almost comforting. But you snap out of it. You push everything back in the box and put it in it's place.
You start organizing the other part of the closet.
You start organizing the other part of the closet.

You're done for today. Your head is still pounding, you're catching your breath as if you were running. It hurts. Everything hurts. So much that plucking your eyeballs out would feel good in confront.
As always, the creature comes back. It asks you again. "What's your choice?"

You watch as the droplets of blood seep out of the cuts, growing bigger and bigger, and eventually sliding off your arm, hitting the ground...plip...plip...plip.
You patch yourself up and head back to the bed, your mind numb from the pain on your arm. You close your eyes, and drift off to a dreamless sleep.

You take the pills, lay your head on your pillow, and close your eyes. Everything in your room begins to swirl in endless colors. Then everything fades to black.
A restless sleep, haunted by vivid nightmares you can't remember.
You choose to clean the floor, but there is so much trash around that you dont know where to begin from....
Gather the trash close to the desk
Gather the trash close to the bed
Gather the trash in the bathroom

You start examining the area under the desk. A load of empty energy drinks, some takeout and lots of tissues, some of them bloody.
While digging in the tissue pile you see some blades...they're kind of everywhere in the room at this point, so you have to be careful not to accidentally cut yourself...I know, ironic.
Wedged in between the trashcan and the wall you spot something brown and crumply, a dead plant.
You pity it, as you see yourself reflected in it.
"You couldn't even take care of a measly plant, no wonder you're in this state now. She would not be proud of what you've become."
You know that. But what can you do about it?...

You look over to the bathroom. The light is too dim to make sense of any of the shadows in there. You catch the reflection of your room. the light shining through the pulled blinds. A figure standing in the center of it. It has black hair, fair complexion, and tired eyes. You tilt your head and step closer to the mirror.
You examine it's face. Dark eyebags, unkept hairstyle, two moles on the cheek.
Some thin facial hair and slight acne.
So different from her, yet so whole.
You look down to your hands. The fingers move, as if testing their joints.
They look so long and bony. The nails bitten and the skin dry.
You look back to the mirror.
It's you, always has been.
For how long have you been gone?
For how long have you been there? You don't know.
You know nothing, yet you acknowledge everything.

You examine the area around the mattress. The blankets are crumpled and have fallen off the mattress. Some old magazines and comics are piled up in a corner, covered in dust. Bloody bandages and tissues are wedged under the mattress.
You are a complete mess of a person. Is this the future that you had envisioned with her? Of course not. You had big dreams. All gone and forgotten now.
There are still parts of the room with trash, which one next?
Gather the trash close to the desk
Gather the trash close to the bed
Gather the trash close to the bathroom

You star cleaning the desk. It's full of dust and crumbs of food. You ask yourself how come ants still haven't invaded your room. While digging in the empty food wrapping, you find loads of empty pill bottles: lithium, antipsychotics, and anxiety medications. You've stopped taking those for a while now, and skipped all of your doctors appointments. It all felt useless, all of your effort and time spent into therapy. Two hospitalizations were enough to make you realize that maybe the problem weren't other people, but you. Right? After all that you blame natural selection, you're just not meant to be in this society.

You put away the empty pill bottles and continue cleaning up, but soon you get interrupted by memories flooding back.
Children laughing and pointing at this girl, hiding behind her hair.
Teenagers whispering behind the shoulders of this young boy.
Disgusted looks of people glancing at you on the street.
You push everything back, you don't want to remember anything. You have no past and no future. You existence right now is just some higher beings punishment.
Just go back at being nothing.

A woman is crying in front of you, her face lined with tears. She covers her mouth, muffling her wails. She asks you what you have done to her child. Where did her daughter go. You don't know; even though she has always been there, you can't see her anymore.
The floor opens under you, plunging you into darkness.
Your whole body flinches. You remember falling in your dream. Nothing else.
You reach under your pillow to get your phone. It's 5.13am.
You open your minifridge in search for water, but you just find empty bottles.
Defeated, you look around your room, in search of another water bottle.
You notice that some parts of your room are less messy.
Right, you were cleaning your room...which part should you clean today?
Right, you were cleaning your room...which part should you clean today?
Right, you were cleaning your room...which part should you clean today?

You start feeling exhausted. You've done a lot today.
You kneel on the carpet, putting your hands on your thighs. For a moment you hear nothing in your head. Your vision blurs, and you feel your minds slip back into the soft and familiar grasp of the creature. It wants what you deserve...

You watch as the droplets of blood seep out of the cuts, growing bigger and bigger, and eventually sliding off your arm, hitting the ground...plip...plip...plip.
You patch yourself up and head back to the bed, your mind numb from the pain on your arm. You close your eyes, and drift off to a dreamless sleep.

You close your eyes and try to focus your mind. You can't go on like this....
As you try to grasp that part of your conscious that wants to get better, you stop.
You fear it. And the fear stops you.
This is what you have always known, it's all you have in your memories.
You don't know who you are outside of this room.
You're still too weak to defeat it.

You take the pills, lay your head on your pillow, and close your eyes. Everything in your room begins to swirl in endless colors. Then everything fades to black.
A restless sleep, haunted by vivid nightmares you can't remember.

While digging in the empty food wrapping, you find loads of empty pill bottles: lithium, antipsychotics, and anxiety medications. You've stopped taking those for a while now, and skipped all of your doctors appointments. It all felt useless, all of your effort and time spent into therapy. Two hospitalizations were enough to make you realize that maybe the problem weren't other people, but you. Right? After all that you blame natural selection, you're just not meant to be in this society.
"It's a warm rainy day, the frogs in your garden are croacking happily and the air is filled with the sweet scent of petricor."

"After spending the morning cleaning up your house you decide to go out in the woods to search for mushrooms, they're going to be needed for the get together with your friends tonight.What will you bring?"
"You put some apples in your basket, as you get hungry easily, and start heading out towards the woods"
"You put your knife in your pocket, and with your basket in hand you head out in the woods"

"As you approach the edges of the forest, you notice that cheery singing of the birds has been replaced by a heavy silence, as if the fog slowling seeping out from the trees had drowned all sounds from within."
"All you hear is the wind and the occasional creaking of the trees. Nothing out of the usual."

"As you venture deeper you start actively looking for mushrooms.
Diving into bushes and looking in dead tree trunks. But no matter how meticulously you search, not one mushroom has been found.
It's as if something has been eating them all."

"Since your hunt has been unsuccesful so far, you decide to try venturing a bit deeper, until you get to a small clearing. A stream flows in the middle of it, and some dead rotting trees are scattered through the clearing."
"The water runs completely clear, and somefish can bee seen swimming in it. You see your reflection in the water, as well as silver figure behind you..."
"You get close to the rotting wood, already spotting some mushrooms growing from it, but your path gets blocked from a silver creature that rises from the tall grass."
"The four legged creature stands tall in front of you. It's breath condensing in the humid air as it huffes at you. It's hoof scratches the ground as it's getting ready to charge."
"You swiftly reach into your basket and toss an apple to it. It seems to appreaciate your sweet treat and calms down. As it munches on the apple you notice the horn on its head. It's a unicorn."

"You pull out your knife and point it at the creature. Your trembling hand against the sharp horn of a unicorn.


As it charges at you, you try to move out of the way, failing.

Days after some hikers will find your impaled body laying in the field, serving it's purpose as mushroom fertilizer."
"As you approach the animal it's form starts changing. The silver hair grows shorter, and it's face flattes, fingers start growing from it's hooves...then you hear it talk."
"Questa torta di mele che hai fatto è veramente buona!...ma tutto bene? Mi sembri un pò pallido. Non mi dire che hai di nuovo mangiato funghi selvatici! Chissà che stavi allucinando..."

It's the woman again. She's hugging you. Your face pressed in her shoulder, as your tears drench her shirt. You feel a huge weight on your chest. It feels tight and you can't breathe.
You come out of your body. Now you can see the both of you. She grabs you by the shoulders, puts her hands on your face, and rips it.
She comes out. The woman is so happy now. Her face painted with relief. You're scared. You feel nauseous. Who is that? You know her. Forgotten. Buried. Where she should be. Her mother always wanted her to come back. Her little treasure. You scream, but no one hears you. No one knows you. No one knows your name.
You wake up screaming, your whole body shaking.
What was that? You feel...miserable.
Right, you were cleaning your room...which part should you clean today?
Right, you were cleaning your room...which part should you clean today?
Right, you were cleaning your room...which part should you clean today?

You can't do it anymore....you want to break. You need to break. Shatter yourself. The urge to just smash your head on the corner of the bathtub is stronger than ever. "Just do it, it will all be over soon...you will finally be free from this room." No, it's going to be too messy..."Then just slit your wrists open, the pain will be momentary..." I don't know...I would feel bad for whoever has top clean up afterwards."Then hang yourself. No mess. No one has to clean up." Now you really want it to shut up. Maybe if you do it it will go away...or you will be stuck with it forever. You know you can make it shut up, the choice is yours.

No, you still don't want to die like this. You use the only coping method that has ever worked for you.
One slice for her father, hoping that he will get his daughter back. One slice for your friends, who were powerless against it all. And one for ■■■■■■, who had to carry it to the tomb.
You watch as the droplets of blood seep out of the cuts, growing bigger and bigger, and eventually sliding off your arm, hitting the ground...plip...plip...plip. You wrap yourself up and go to bed, hoping for a better tomorrow.

You're too tired...too weak. You try with all of your determination but it's useless. The memories keep flooding back and there's no stopping them.
But you still don't want to die like this. You use the only coping method that has ever worked for you.
One slice for her father, hoping that he will get his daughter back. One slice for your friends, who were powerless against it all. And one for ■■■■■■, who had to carry it to the tomb.
You watch as the droplets of blood seep out of the cuts, growing bigger and bigger, and eventually sliding off your arm, hitting the ground...plip...plip...plip. You wrap yourself up and go to bed, hoping for a better tomorrow.

You cave in to the creatures sweet words...You take your blanket and head to the bathroom. You yank off the shower curtain and tie the blanket to it, then you make a noose for your neck. You climb on the edge of the tub, and jump.
It won. You'll be forgotten, and she will live on, etched forever in stone in your memory.
Dear daughter and friend.

Two hospitalizations were enough to make you realize that maybe the problem weren't other people, but you. Right? After all that you blame natural selection, you're just not meant to be in this society.

You hear the sound of birds. People talking in the distance. The trees singing with the wind. It's a beautiful morning in May. Yet there's blood on the grass.
The boy is 17, prime of his life, yet he wishes for it to end. His arm drenched in blood...plip...plip...plip, drops of blood fall on the ground. He takes a deep breath, ready for the consequences. He knows he's going to get hospitalized for this, that's what he planned for. Maybe there he will get the help he needs, or maybe he'll know he's too far gone.
You wake up. Your arm stings. You haven't gone this deep since that day.

You reach under your pillow and pull out your phone, its 7.15am.
You will get it done today.
You wake up and you go to the bathroom. It's so full of trash you don't know where to begin.

You chose to clean the sink. It's crusty with grime and dried blood. The drain is plugged with hair you've cut. You look up to the mirror.
Your hair grew longer. It makes you look feminine.
You grab the scissors and start cutting them, chunks falling in the sink.
Now they're short again, you recognize yourself a bit better.
You look over to the side of the faucet, where bottles of testosterone are laying empty.
You were so excited when you started. The changes came in quick, and you got more confident. But mental illnesses stay no matter what external changes you get.
Still, 17 year old you would be happy.
You throw the hair in the toilet and scrub the sink. Now it's clean.

You chose to clean the bathtub. It's dusty and a bit mouldy, given the absence of a window in the bathroom. You gather the empty bottles of shampoo and throw them in the trash.
You used to sit here for hours on end, before it got too dirty to even get into. The tight space made you feel safe, and it's pretty cool to sleep in during the summer season.
you haven't taken a bath in so long.
You open the cabinet. It's full of bandages, single use razors and disinfectant. Surprisingly, it's the only clean and tidy part of the room.
There are still parts of the bathroom with trash, which one next?

As soon as you stop moving it comes back, but this time it pulsates through you. It's voice louder than ever, as if it's coming out from your own thoughts. "Give up. Give up. Give up. Give up. GIVE IT TO ME. IT'S MINE." It asks for your body and mind. What a empty husk you have become.
Your eyelids flutter close, and your body goes limp. Has your time come? Will you give me up? Will I give up...

I give up. I'm tired. I'm broken. Let me go.
It won. You'll be forgotten, and she will live on, etched forever in stone in your memory.
Dear daughter and friend.

No. I won't give up. Not after all those years fighting to be myself. Not after all the pain and discrimination I've endured. I will not give up. I got better once and I will again, no matter how much time or how many tries it will take me. You won't have me.
Silence falls. I did it.
You remember avoiding showering as a teenager because you hated how feminine your body was; and if you had to you would do it with the lights turned off. Should I shower, perhaps?
Your eyelids flutter close, and your body goes limp. Has your time come? Will you give me up? Will I give up...
It's better not to, it would take you too much energy. And you don't like showering anyways, makes you sick of your own body.

You decide to shower. You throw all of your weeks old pyjamas on the floor and start the water. You stand under the running hot water, taking a deep breath. It doesn't feel bad. You feel your shoulders relaxing.
You grab the body soap and start scrubbing your chest. You notice your top surgery scars, now pink from the heat of the water. It's been a few years now, since you went to Germany to get operated. Sure, your mother wasn't accepting, but she helped you pay for it anyways. She wasn't a bad mother, but you still didn't know how to feel about her. She did want her daughter back, but after years of having a son she finally managed to at least call you by your name.
You turn off the shower and dry yourself. You feel more present mentally.
